texts.definition: Mastery of performing actions and reaching goals in a game.
markups: <style="Definition">Mastery of performing actions and reaching goals in a game.</style>

Games challenges players in reaching goals and performing gameplay actions. Those games which allow players to become skillful in repeatedly succeeding with these allow players to develop <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style> in them.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Chess">Chess</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Go">Go</link></style> are classical examples of games in which <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style> consists of knowing sequences of actions, being able to think many steps ahead, and knowing how one's opponent thinks. Being good at <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Guts">Guts</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Poker">Poker</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Texas%20Hold'em">Texas Hold'em</link></style> also rely on the latter of these but combined with an understanding of the probabilities of possible outcomes together with a skill in bluffing. In contrast, games such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead%20series">Left 4 Dead series</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Street%20Fighter%20series">Street Fighter series</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Quake%20series">Quake series</link></style> require fast reactions and good hand-eye coordination; although knowing how one's enemies behave is also important especially in games against other players <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Multiplayer%20Online%20Battle%20Arena%20Games">MOBA Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Defense%20of%20the%20Ancients">Defense of the Ancients</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/League%20of%20Legends">League of Legends</link></style> similarly requires both manual dexterity and outthinking one's opponents.

As a game with no gameplay, <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style> is impossible to achieve <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Progress%20Quest">Progress Quest</link></style>. Story-driven games, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Adventure%20Games">Adventure Games</link></style>, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Day%20of%20the%20Tentacle">Day of the Tentacle</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fahrenheit">Fahrenheit</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Grim%20Fandango">Grim Fandango</link></style>, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Walking%20Dead%20series">Walking Dead series</link></style>, have little or no gameplay that allows specific skills or knowledge to develop that can be re-used so claiming <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style> in these are difficult to do. The exception may be in general puzzle solving based on the types of puzzle that exist in a particular genre or that a particular game designer creates.

Given that <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style> is mastering the specific gameplay of a game, there are as many ways of supporting <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style> as there are gameplay which involve some type of skill or knowledge. Perhaps the clearest way of offering <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style> is to provide <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dominant%20Strategies">Dominant Strategies</link></style> but if this is a viable design solution depends on if a game is a <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Game</link></style> (since its presence will make <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style> impossible) and to which extent the game should provide <style="Link"><link="replayability">Replayability</link></style>. It can also be questionable since knowing the best way to play can lessen players' <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> since there are typically only one or a few choices that are the best. Still on a general level, <style="Link"><link="complex-gameplay">Complex Gameplay</link></style> makes knowing the rules of a game part of reaching <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style> while <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style> guarantees that there is something to train at getting good at (or makes it more difficult to achieve <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style>). However, being able to fully master a game can undo the challenging aspect of the gameplay so the patterns can work against each other, especially if <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dominant%20Strategies">Dominant Strategies</link></style> exists.

One aspect of <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style> concerns being able to plan what to do in a game. This makes <style="Link"><link="predictable-consequences">Predictable Consequences</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk/Reward">Risk/Reward</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="stimulated-planning">Stimulated Planning</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="strategic-knowledge">Strategic Knowledge</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="tactical-planning">Tactical Planning</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="trade-offs">Trade-Offs</link></style> ways of allowing <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style> to develop among players. More specific design features that support this are <style="Link"><link="card-building">Card Building</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="deck-building">Deck Building</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="puzzle-solving">Puzzle Solving</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="resource-management">Resource Management</link></style>. While the two latter of these taken place during gameplay, <style="Link"><link="card-building">Card</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="deck-building">Deck Building</link></style> can also occur before gameplay proper begins. Knowing when to do <style="Link"><link="construction-scoring-phase-shift">Construction/Scoring Phase Shifts</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="speedending">Speedending</link></style> are specific examples, and players that know this will affect the <style="Link"><link="middlegame">Middlegame</link></style> of games. Planning and creating <style="Link"><link="flip-flop-events">Flip-Flop Events</link></style> is another specific aspect of <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style> which is possible in games with mutable <style="Link"><link="turn-taking">Turn Taking</link></style>. Games with <style="Link"><link="construction">Construction</link></style> that can be used to create <style="Link"><link="combos">Combos</link></style> or lead to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Emergent%20Gameplay">Emergent Gameplay</link></style> can also allow for <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style>. On a general level, knowing how and when to perform <style="Link"><link="extended-actions">Extended Actions</link></style> in games which have them is also a source for <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style>. Another, related, aspect of <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style> is having the information or knowledge needed to perform gameplay actions. Games with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Paper-Rock-Scissors">Paper-Rock-Scissors</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="sidegrades">Sidegrades</link></style> require players to keep track of the game state to know when different actions should be made, and having this awareness is a common part of <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style>. Knowing which <style="Link"><link="excluding-goals">Excluding Goals</link></style> to choose depending on the game situation can also be a sign of <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style> although the mere presence of <style="Link"><link="excluding-goals">Excluding Goals</link></style> does not guarantee the possibility to have <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style> in a game. Having <style="Link"><link="real-world-knowledge-advantages">Real World Knowledge Advantages</link></style>, e.g. about detailed pertaining to <style="Link"><link="seamful-gameplay">Seamful Gameplay</link></style>, or keeping track of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Trans-Game%20Information">Trans-Game Information</link></style> can allow for <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style> before gameplay begin, while <style="Link"><link="memorizing">Memorizing</link></style> allows it to take place during gameplay.

Being able to perform gameplay actions is also often a part of having <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style>. The numerous ways this can be tested include <style="Link"><link="betting">Betting</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="bluffing">Bluffing</link></style> (in games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Poker">Poker</link></style>), building <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pre-Customized%20Decks">Pre-Customized Decks</link></style>, performing <style="Link"><link="dexterity-based-actions">Dexterity-Based Actions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="enactment">Enactment</link></style>, handling <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Resources">Limited Resources</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Negotiation">Negotiation</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="player-physical-prowess">Player Physical Prowess</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="rhythm-based-actions">Rhythm-Based Actions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="social-skills">Social Skills</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="storytelling">Storytelling</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Timing">Timing</link></style>, and controlling <style="Link"><link="vehicles">Vehicles</link></style>. More contextual examples include being able to <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplay</link></style> that one is not the one that performed certain <style="Link"><link="anonymous-actions">Anonymous Actions</link></style> or performing <style="Link"><link="combos">Combos</link></style> in games with <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="complex-gameplay">Complex Gameplay</link></style>. Slightly more general, avoiding <style="Link"><link="obstacles">Obstacles</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="overcome">Overcoming</link></style> enemies require gameplay actions that performing well signals <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style>. <style="Link"><link="competence-areas">Competence Areas</link></style> is an overarching way to provide <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style> since any game with <style="Link"><link="competence-areas">Competence Areas</link></style> by definition has areas in which players can become proficient. In <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style> can both consist of being able to do <style="Link"><link="collaborative-actions">Collaborative Actions</link></style> and presenting <style="Link"><link="player-unpredictability">Player Unpredictability</link></style> to other players.

<style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style> also requires that players have sufficiently difficult goals to try and complete. <style="Link"><link="predefined-goals">Predefined Goals</link></style> naturally provides such goals but only if they are difficult enough to challenge players. On a general level, <style="Link"><link="further-player-improvement-potential">Further Player Improvement Potential</link></style> provides this and games that encourage players to have <style="Link"><link="fubar-enjoyment">FUBAR Enjoyment</link></style> at least place players in difficult situations. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Perceivable%20Margins">Perceivable Margins</link></style> gives players information on how they could have performed better and thereby supports players with improving their potential. Skill-based <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> let players have <style="Link"><link="further-player-improvement-potential">Further Player Improvement Potential</link></style> as long as more skilled players can be found and is for this reason a very common design features that supports the presence of <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Smooth%20Learning%20Curves">Smooth Learning Curves</link></style> guide players so they don't start with too difficult challenges but may require players to play through too easy before getting to parts which match their skill levels. <style="Link"><link="difficulty-levels">Difficulty Levels</link></style> in contrast let players set an appropriate level for themselves (potentially with <style="Link"><link="ai-players">AI Players</link></style> of varying difficulties); the danger to this solution being that players can satisfy themselves with being able to complete a game at a certain <style="Link"><link="difficulty-levels">Difficulty Level</link></style> and not push themselves to their full potential. Another danger is that <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style> may make the <style="Link"><link="difficulty-levels">Difficulty Levels</link></style> meaningless since all of them may be too easy for an expert player. <style="Link"><link="achievements">Achievements</link></style> and the possibility of <style="Link"><link="speedruns">Speedruns</link></style> encourage players to play in ways that typically are more difficult and thereby motivate players to fully develop a <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style> as long as the <style="Link"><link="achievements">Achievements</link></style> and the challenges of <style="Link"><link="speedruns">Speedruns</link></style> match the gameplay challenges of the game. <style="Link"><link="goal-achievements">Goal Achievements</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="handicap-achievements">Handicap Achievements</link></style> specifically can modify how players try to reach <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style> by pointing out certain goals or ways a game can be played which makes it harder (the former can for example be based upon showing that one can perform <style="Link"><link="repeat-combos">Repeat Combos</link></style>). While having <style="Link"><link="experimenting">Experimenting</link></style> as part of gameplay does not necessarily in itself provide skills that allow <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style> but can allow players to try different types of actions and therefore promote players to reach <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style>.

While maybe not allowing for <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style> in themselves, several design features can motivate players more to try and achieve the mastery which is possible. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Symmetry">Symmetry</link></style> can ensure that <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style> is foregrounded in gameplay rather than luck in starting positions. In contrast, <style="Link"><link="uncertainty-outcome">Uncertainty of Outcome</link></style> can make <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style> less likely to guarantee winning or dominance in gameplay while still allowing those with <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style> the possibility of displaying it and having advantages of having it. <style="Link"><link="repetitive-gameplay">Repetitive Gameplay</link></style> puts focus on a specific type of gameplay and requires players to show a skill in it (if a skill for it exists) as well as lets players train at being good at it. It can however of course also limit how much gameplay there is to master. <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Red%20Queen%20Dilemmas">Red Queen Dilemmas</link></style> can require display of <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style> to be important throughout a game instance although they do make skillful gaming in the beginning of a game instance less important. <style="Link"><link="high-score-lists">High Score Lists</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="public-player-statistics">Public Player Statistics</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="spectators">Spectators</link></style> appeal to players' wishes to show themselves as good players (e.g. showing <style="Link"><link="spectators">Spectators</link></style> that they can achieve <style="Link"><link="repeat-combos">Repeat Combos</link></style>). <style="Link"><link="tournaments">Tournaments</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="meta-games">Meta Games</link></style> that allow players to perceive each other's skills can provide the same kind of display of game mastery. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Asymmetric%20Abilities">Asymmetric Abilities</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="varied-gameplay">Varied Gameplay</link></style> can make people have different types of <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style> in a game as well as make <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style> of the game as a whole require many different types of competences. <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style> can accomplish the same thing by having varying types of challenges between <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style> and also through supporting <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Smooth%20Learning%20Curves">Smooth Learning Curves</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> is a way for a game to explicitly show that a player has displayed some type of <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style> while handling <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> well can be a type of <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style>. <style="Link"><link="illusionary-rewards">Illusionary Rewards</link></style> can work like <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> in this sense, supporting or motivating players to develop their gameplay, while giving players <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Engrossment">Engrossment</link></style> simply makes players more likely to become better at a game because they are more likely to playing it more.

Several design features in a game can work against <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style>. Many of them do this by limiting the effects of player skills, e.g. <style="Link"><link="auto-aim">Auto-Aim</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="balancing-effects">Balancing Effects</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style> (and thereby <style="Link"><link="luck">Luck</link></style>). This category of design features also includes ways of easing player challenges by making the game itself help, e.g. through <style="Link"><link="player-augmentations">Player Augmentations</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="vision-modes">Vision Modes</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="player-character-skill-composites">Player/Character Skill Composites</link></style> when <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> have <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="purchasable-game-advantages">Purchasable Game Advantages</link></style> also works against <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style> since one player can get the same progress, <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style>, etc. through paying as another can through his or her <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style>. <style="Link"><link="clickability">Clickability</link></style> removes explorative aspects of gameplay which may work against a certain type of <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style> in a game but can also focus what is the actual skills needed in a game by removing the exploratory aspect.

A part of having <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style> often requires players to have a systemic understanding of a game. This makes it difficult to not reduce diegetic representations of people to their functions and mechanical behaviors. Due to this, players may have difficulties getting <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Emotional%20Engrossment">Emotional Engrossment</link></style> with <style="Link"><link="algorithmic-agents">Algorithmic Agents</link></style> if they have <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style>.

Allowing players to feel <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style> or at least see that they can have it in the future can have several consequences for a game. It can give players <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Emotional%20Engrossment">Emotional Engrossment</link></style> and a sense of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Empowerment">Empowerment</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="player-agency">Player Agency</link></style>, and provide <style="Link"><link="value-effort">Value of Effort</link></style> when players experience having it. In general, it provides <style="Link"><link="replayability">Replayability</link></style> to a game since players may wish to play the game many times to reach <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style>. A negative effect of <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style> is that players that have it can lead to games having a <style="Link"><link="predictable-winner">Predictable Winner</link></style>.

Having <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style> can be a <style="Link"><link="social-rewards">Social Reward</link></style> if others can notice it and can support <style="Link"><link="actor-detachment">Actor Detachment</link></style>. For games with <style="Link"><link="cooperation">Cooperation</link></style> and different possible roles for players to take, <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style> can lead to <style="Link"><link="role-fulfillment">Role Fulfillment</link></style> and through this fulfilling <style="Link"><link="social-roles">Social Roles</link></style> and making <style="Link"><link="team-development">Team Development</link></style> happen. In all games with other players, the presence of <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style> affects the <style="Link"><link="performance-uncertainty">Performance Uncertainty</link></style> of skilled players and can ruin an <style="Link"><link="exaggerated-perception-influence">Exaggerated Perception of Influence</link></style> among those not skilled that observe them.

The ability of players to have <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style> affects <style="Link"><link="player-character-skill-composites">Player/Character Skill Composites</link></style>, so games with this patterns need to take into consideration how <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style> will affect it as at an extreme it may make the <style="Link"><link="characters">Character</link></style> aspect unimportant and may make it difficult to have mechanics that create <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style>.

In games with <style="Link"><link="cooperation">Cooperation</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Negotiation">Negotiation</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Gameplay Mastery</style> can lead to <style="Link"><link="reflective-communication">Reflective Communication</link></style>.

<style="Link"><link="actor-detachment">Actor Detachment</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Emotional%20Engrossment">Emotional Engrossment</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Empowerment">Empowerment</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="player-agency">Player Agency</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="predictable-winner">Predictable Winner</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="social-roles">Social Roles</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="replayability">Replayability</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="role-fulfillment">Role Fulfillment</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="social-rewards">Social Rewards</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="team-development">Team Development</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="value-effort">Value of Effort</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="achievements">Achievements</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="betting">Betting</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="bluffing">Bluffing</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="competence-areas">Competence Areas</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="complex-gameplay">Complex Gameplay</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="construction-scoring-phase-shift">Construction/Scoring Phase Shift</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="collaborative-actions">Collaborative Actions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="deck-building">Deck Building</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="dexterity-based-actions">Dexterity-Based Actions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="difficulty-levels">Difficulty Levels</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dominant%20Strategies">Dominant Strategies</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="enactment">Enactment</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="experimenting">Experimenting</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="extended-actions">Extended Actions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="flip-flop-events">Flip-Flop Events</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="fubar-enjoyment">FUBAR Enjoyment</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="further-player-improvement-potential">Further Player Improvement Potential</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Resources">Limited Resources</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="memorizing">Memorizing</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Negotiation">Negotiation</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="obstacles">Obstacles</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="overcome">Overcome</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Paper-Rock-Scissors">Paper-Rock-Scissors</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Perceivable%20Margins">Perceivable Margins</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="player-physical-prowess">Player Physical Prowess</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="player-unpredictability">Player Unpredictability</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pre-Customized%20Decks">Pre-Customized Decks</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="predefined-goals">Predefined Goals</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="predictable-consequences">Predictable Consequences</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="puzzle-solving">Puzzle Solving</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="real-world-knowledge-advantages">Real World Knowledge Advantages</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="resource-management">Resource Management</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="rhythm-based-actions">Rhythm-Based Actions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk/Reward">Risk/Reward</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="seamful-gameplay">Seamful Gameplay</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="sidegrades">Sidegrades</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Smooth%20Learning%20Curves">Smooth Learning Curves</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="social-skills">Social Skills</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="speedending">Speedending</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="speedruns">Speedruns</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="stimulated-planning">Stimulated Planning</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="storytelling">Storytelling</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="strategic-knowledge">Strategic Knowledge</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="tactical-planning">Tactical Planning</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Timing">Timing</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="trade-offs">Trade-Offs</link></style>,
